content: The absolute value of a value is the distance from 0 on the number line. Since distances are always positive: $|x|\in \{0, \mathbb{Z}\}$ Example  To solve abosolute values, split $|x|$ to $-x$ and $+x$. $$|2x+3|\le 4$$ $$2x+3\le 4, -2x-3\le 4$$ $$2x\le 1, -2x\le 7$$ $$x\le \frac{1}{2}, x\ge \frac{-7}{2}$$ $$\frac{-7}{2}\le x\le \frac{1}{2}$$
title: Absolute Values

For any function $g(x)$, get the parent function $f(x)$ and put it into the following form: $$g(x)=af(k(x-d))+c$$
Each parent function has the domain and range (common ones are listed in u8/pfn#common-parent-functions  ). To get the domain and range of the function, substitute the $x$ in the domain and the $y$ in the range to $x-d$ and $y-c$.
Example  To get the domain and range of $(x)$, where $f(x)=\sqrt{x}$, and where $g(x)=\sqrt{x-3}=af(k(x-d))+c$, substitute $x-d$ for $x$ and $y-c$ for $y$: $d=3, d\in \mathbb{R}, x-d=x-3$
$c=0, y-c=y, c\in \mathbb{R}$
$D\{x+d\in \mathbb{R} | x-d\ge 0\}$
$D\{x\in \mathbb{R} | x\ge 3\}$
$R\{y+c\in \mathbb{R} | y-c\ge 0\}$
$R\{y\in \mathbb{R} | y\ge 0\}$

content:
The inverse of a function reverses the operation that the function does.
For example, if $f(x)=x^2$ then $f^{-1}(x)=x^{\frac{1}{2}}$ and therefore $f(f^{-1}(x))=x$.
To determine the inverse of a function, reverse the uses of $x$ and $y$.
$$f(x)=y=2x^3+4$$ (flip $x$ and $y$)
$$f^{-1}(x)=(\frac{x-4}{2})^\frac{1}{3}$$
title: Inverses of Functions

content:
Even functions satisfy $f(x) = f(-x)$. (notice how even functions have even exponents (i.e. $\frac{n}{2} \in \mathbb{Z}$ in $y=x^n+c$)) For example, $y = |x|$ is even, and therefore it is symmetric on the y axis:  an even function          Figure with identifier even-func : an even function   For example, $f$ is even, where $f(x) = -x^2-2x^2+4$, since $f(-x) = -(-x)^2-2(-x)^2+4 = -x^2+2x^2+4 = f(x)$.
Odd functions (奇関数) satisfy $f(x) = -f(-x)$. For example, $y = x$ is odd, and therefore it is mirrored on both the $x$ and $y$ axes.  an even function          Figure with identifier odd-func : an even function   Example  $f$ is odd, where $f(x) = x^3+4x$, since $-f(-x) = -((-x)^3+4(-x)) = -(-x^3-4x) = x^3+4x = f(x)$.
 Functions that are neither even or odd do not meet any of the requirements.
Example  $f$ is neither, where $f(x)=\sqrt{x}$, since $-f(-x) = -(\sqrt{-x}) = -\sqrt{-x} \ne f(x)$, and since $f(-x) = \sqrt{-x} \ne f(x)$.

For functions of the form $g(x)=af(x-d)+c$, constants $a$, $d$, and $c$ change the shape or location of the graph of $g(x)$.
 $y=|x|$            Figure with identifier u8l7abs : $y=|x|$    $y=-|x|$            Figure with identifier u8l7rx : $y=-|x|$   Mapping rule: $(x, y) \rightarrow (\frac{x}{b}+h)(ay+k)$ For any function with the form: $g(x)=af(b(x-h))+k$ )
Constants:
 $a$ vertical stretch/compression $b$ horizontal stretch/compression $h$ vertical translation $k$ horizontal translation  Transformations: For this equation, $y=af(b(x-h))+k$ :
 Vertical Scaling (using $a$)  If $|a| > 1$: vs by $|a|$. Else if $0 < |a| < 1$: vc by $|a|$.   Vertical Reflection (using $a$)  If $a < 0$: reflect on x-axis.   Horizontal Scaling (using $b$)  If $|b| > 1$: hs by $\frac{1}{|b|}$. Else if $0 < |b| < 1$: hc by $\frac{1}{|b|}$.   Horizontal Reflection (using $b$)  If $b < 0$: reflect on y-axis.   Horizontal Translation (using $h$)  If $h > 0$: ht $h$ right. Else uf $h < 0$: ht $h$ left.   Horizontal Translation (using $k$)  If $k > 0$: vt $k$ up. Else uf $k < 0$: vt $k$ down.    An invariant point is a point that is unchanged by a transformation. (not exactly the same a invariants in computer science)

content:
$f(x)$ is pronounced as “f of x”, “f at x”, among many others. It means to replace $f(x)$ with the definition of $f(x)$.
For example, if $f(x)=x+1$, $f(1) = 1+1 = 2$ and $f(y) = x+y$.
 a function a function for use in the example below         Figure with identifier func : a function a function for use in the example below
  $f(0) = 0$
Composition of Functions Function composition is a useful way to make new functions. It is done using the $\circ$ operator.
$(f\circ g)(x) = f(g(x))$
This is pronounced as “f composed with g of x” ($g\circ f$ is pronounced “g composed with f”).
Note that this is similar to the funtion composition operator (.) in Haskell.
For example, if $g(x)=5x^2+1$, and $f(x)=x+1$, then $g(f(x)) = (g\circ f)(x) = g(x+1) = 5(x+1)^2+1$

content:
Definitions Let $x$, $y$ represent an independent, and dependent variable, respectively.
A relation defines relations between two sets.
It can also be represented as a set of ordered pairs with two values, $x$ and $y$.
It can also be defined as a referentially transparent and side-effect-free procedure (in computer science).
Relation = List[Tuple[complex, complex]]
A function is a relation where each value of $x$ corresponds with only one value of $y$.
The domain of a relation is the set of all values of $x$.
def domain(relation): return [s[0] for s in relation] The range of a relation is the set of all values of $y$.
def range(relation): return [s[1] for s in relation] Determine if a Relation is a Function Vertical Line Test The vertical line test can be used to determine whether a relation is a function. If for every vertical line on the appropriate plane, there exists only one point where the vertical line intersects the relation, the relation is a function.
An example of a relation:
 circle a circle centred at the origin, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points         Figure with identifier circ : circle a circle centred at the origin, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points

 linear a linear equation, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points         Figure with identifier lin : linear a linear equation, which fails the vertical line test because a vertical line at x=0 goes through two points

Quick Reference Mapping rule: $(x, y) \rightarrow (\frac{x}{b}+h)(ay+k)$ Transformations for a function: $y=af(b(x-h))+k$ (or $y=af(k(x-h))+c$ )
Transformations: For this equation, $y=af(b(x-h))+k$ :
 Vertical Scaling (using $a$)  If $|a| > 1$: vs by $|a|$. Else if $0 < |a| < 1$: vc by $|a|$.   Vertical Reflection (using $a$)  If $a < 0$: reflect on x-axis.   Horizontal Scaling (using $b$)  If $|b| > 1$: hs by $\frac{1}{|b|}$. Else if $0 < |b| < 1$: hc by $\frac{1}{|b|}$.   Horizontal Reflection (using $b$)  If $b < 0$: reflect on y-axis.   Horizontal Translation (using $h$)  If $h > 0$: ht $h$ right. Else uf $h < 0$: ht $h$ left.   Horizontal Translation (using $k$)  If $k > 0$: vt $k$ up. Else uf $k < 0$: vt $k$ down.    NOTE: Sets (e.g. domain and range) do not have repeats (e.g. $\{1, 2\}$ ).
NOTE: expand the macro/function as well when doing the equation (i.e. $y=|x+2|$ not $g(x)=|x|, y=g(x+2)$ )

$M_{AB}=(\frac{x_1+x_2}{2}, \frac{x_1+x_2}{2})$ where $A(x_1, y_1)$ and $B(x_2, y_2)$
Bisecting lines share their midpoints. For example, in parallelograms, the diagonals bisect each other.
A right bisector is a line that bisects another line and intersects it by a $90°$ angle.

 Inside the triangle Each median divides the triangle into two smaller triangles of equal area The centroid divides medians into segments whose length have the same ratio as $2:1$  Orthocentre The orthocentre is the intersection of the altitudes of a triangle
